Bas 04-Nov-21 04:33 PM
In simple words, the more data you write to the global ledger database, the more IOTA you need to deposit in the output. This is not a fee, because the deposited coins can be reclaimed by consuming the output in a new transaction.
Bingo! The use case for owning IOTA tokens. And the protocol remains feeless, albeit not without costs.

Native tokens are injected into the IOTA ledger by users; therefore they are also called user-defined tokens. They consume precious resources of nodes maintaining the network, mostly storage. I look forward to more discussion on these 2 topics, and I think that this is a very powerful approach that will enable a lot of use cases. In particular, the NFT Avatar that has it's own iota address seems like we're stepping right into Ready Player One.

B.Kind 04-Nov-21 05:16 PM
@Dr. Muon [Real Electric Grinch] Yes, win-win from the tokenomics perspective, but we'll need to make it user friendly. I think of the early days of EOS where you needed to somehow buy RAM and CPU to perform a transaction. It was a pain. This proposal is more like using IOTA's as a returnable deposit while you occupy data storage on the tangle. And so, it's not a fee. It will be important to communicate with the right metaphors for it to make sense to the general public while also having a super simple UI for ease of use.

ivan666 04-Nov-21 05:28 PM
Transacting with NFTs is feeless, like any other IOTA transaction, and the current owner is in full control of either transferring the token with the attached metadata or burning it. The NFT output was designed with smart contract interoperability in mind, therefore it is possible to send it as part of a smart contract request, for example, to deposit it to a smart contract chain as collateral or listing it for auction. Sounds very interesting!

Levente Pap [IF] 04-Nov-21 06:12 PM
Just to get it straight, you store your tokens in an output that have an address. The more different kind of user defined tokens there are in your output, the more the dust deposit will be. It is actually efficient to store all your tokens in one output, because than you don't have to have deposit for the overhead of creating many outputs that belong to your address. (edited)

Werner [VOTE BUIDL!] 04-Nov-21 08:34 PM
Ethereum has the gas system. Each operation is assigned a gas cost and you have to pay for each operation at runtime. You also specify a limit how much gas you want to spend, if you reach it the transaction is reverted.

just4fun 04-Nov-21 09:24 PM
Let me try an ELI5: New dust protection: You have to deposit iota tokens to pay for the storage of your transaction. The amount depends on the size of your transaction (i.e. how many Bytes have to be stored by the nodes) and you get the deposit amount back when the nodes can delete your transaction. New UTXO types (tokenization framework): You can do all sorts of stuff with this. You can create NFTs and native assets (formerly known as colored coins) on L1. You can define your own token creation scheme for native assets (e.g. create inflationary or deflationary currencies). You can use them to transfer tokens from one smart contract chain to another smart contract chain (i.e. switch between different L2s). You can send tokens to someone and if he didn't use them after a certain time (defined by you) you will get them back. You can define a timelock for tokens, i.e. you can define that those tokens can only be spent again after a certain amount of time. (This can e.g. be used to make sure that the pledged aMana can't be revoked again for the defined timeframe). The new dust protection also allows you to permanently store data on the tangle (e.g. DIDs) without the need for permanodes. And so much more. It's a framework that is really designed to be as flexible as possible. All of these usecases require the nodes to store additional data and with the new dust protection this means that you have to deposit iotas for this which results in an increased token demand. And since you get your deposit back when your UTXO gets consumed, all of this is still feeless. (edited)

just4fun
Let me try an ELI5: New dust protection: You have to deposit iota tokens to pay for the storage of your transaction. The amount depends on the size of your transaction (i.e. how many Bytes have to be stored by the nodes) and you get the deposit amount back when the nodes can delete your transaction. New UTXO types (tokenization framework): You can do all sorts of stuff with this. You can create NFTs and native assets (formerly known as colored coins) on L1. You can define your own token creation scheme for native assets (e.g. create inflationary or deflationary currencies). You can use them to transfer tokens from one smart contract chain to another smart contract chain (i.e. switch between different L2s). You can send tokens to someone and if he didn't use them after a certain time (defined by you) you will get them back. You can define a timelock for tokens, i.e. you can define that those tokens can only be spent again after a certain amount of time. (This can e.g. be used to make sure that the pledged aMana can't be revoked again for the defined timeframe). The new dust protection also allows you to permanently store data on the tangle (e.g. DIDs) without the need for permanodes. And so much more. It's a framework that is really designed to be as flexible as possible. All of these usecases require the nodes to store additional data and with the new dust protection this means that you have to deposit iotas for this which results in an increased token demand. And since you get your deposit back when your UTXO gets consumed, all of this is still feeless. (edited)

Navin Ramachandran [IF Grinch] 04-Nov-21 10:13 PM
It is a bit complex to grasp because we have tried to tackle many things at the same time with a unified system. 1) The dust problem. This means if I send 1i to a million addresses using 1Mi, it takes a lot lot more space to store that on the IOTA ledger. 1 Mi on an address: store 1 address. 1i on a million addresses: you now have to store a million addresses. (I have simplified this to avoid explaining utxo‚Äôs) So we need a mechanism to stop people attacking the network by doing this. 2) When we introduce native tokens and NFTs, these essentially behave like 1i transfers but even worse because they involve 0i. So to prevent attackers filling up the database with nonsense data we use the same protection. Remember that the feeless nature of IOTA means that we encounter these problems well before other protocols. So these are issues that affect everyone. We just have to be ahead of the curve to deal with them.

Olaf van Wijk [Nihilium.io] 04-Nov-21 10:28 PM
Using stake to obtain a dust protection is indeed a much more general approach to keep dust alive. However you still need the nodes itself to provide the proofs. This is why I wrote the [https://iota.cafe/t/old-and-dust-tx-merkle-tree-bitmasked-snapshot-compression/1185] article as part of my selective permanode work. Which ended up to be the utreexo approach. Which is widely recognized already. The idea was to place the burden of proof with those who would want to use dust instead of with the rest of the network.

Werner [VOTE BUIDL!] 04-Nov-21 11:16 PM
A simple case (assuming 1400i/vByte; some values rounded): Simple transaction: 1Mi minimum +100Ki for each native token you are carrying around +12,6Ki if you make use of the return block +7Ki for each of the 4 locking/expiration blocks +500Ki if you are adding a sender +370Ki if its an NFT with issuer (although without data at this point) and then 1,4Ki per byte of additional metadata (e.g. the actual data of NFTs or just data you want to store alongside your transaction) (edited)

Werner [VOTE BUIDL!]
A simple case (assuming 1400i/vByte; some values rounded): Simple transaction: 1Mi minimum +100Ki for each native token you are carrying around +12,6Ki if you make use of the return block +7Ki for each of the 4 locking/expiration blocks +500Ki if you are adding a sender +370Ki if its an NFT with issuer (although without data at this point) and then 1,4Ki per byte of additional metadata (e.g. the actual data of NFTs or just data you want to store alongside your transaction) (edited)
